Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2024, starting with year 1.

Overview

Overview
All students will benefit from a series of skills training sessions in semester 2 of year 2, delivered by Careers & Employability (C&E). They will be encouraged to seek a ‘traditional’ placement that will help them develop graduate-level skills, in any professional sector. If students are successful in obtaining a placement, this will be undertaken in the summer between years 2 and 3.

If students are not successful in obtaining, or do not wish to undertake a ‘traditional’ placement, they will instead engage in a virtual placement, to be undertaken either in the summer, or in semester 1 of year 3. Students will choose from one of four broad categories of placement, public health, environment and sustainability, biotechnology, and general careers. By engaging with skills development activities online, students will further develop their employability skills such as critical thinking, interpretation, and communication.

In semester 2 of year 3, all students will undertake a further series of training sessions, incorporating group work, and again delivered by C&E. All students, regardless of which placement activity they undertake, will be assessed via a reflective portfolio, that they will develop throughout their engagement with the module activities.

For those students undertaking a placement external to the university, costs may be associated with travel to and from the student’s placement site, and (temporary) accommodation if the student has to stay away from their normal term-time accommodation whilst attending the placement. Students will be made fully aware of these expenses, and the possibility of reimbursement will be considered on individual basis, where appropriate.
Educational Aims
The aim of this module is to prepare students for graduate-level work. The module aims to give students the opportunity to further develop their skills and professional behaviours, reflect on them, and evidence them for future employment.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This 15-credit year three module acts as a steppingstone for students into the world of work. The module will utilise and develop knowledge, understanding, and skills that students have acquired during their first five semesters of study. Incorporating a placement, it will provide an opportunity for students to improve skills that are particularly sought after by employers, such as problem solving, teamwork, and communication, and will train them to better recognise, evidence, and articulate their skillset to future employers. The module will be assessed via a reflective portfolio, that they will develop throughout their engagement with the module activities.

For those students undertaking a placement external to the university, costs may be associated with travel to and from the student’s placement site, and (temporary) accommodation if the student has to stay away from their normal term-time accommodation whilst attending the placement. Students will be made fully aware of these expenses, and the possibility of reimbursement will be considered on individual basis, where appropriate.
Outline Syllabus
This module will be divided into a pre-placement phase, consisting of seminars for preparation to the placement, a core applied phase, consisting of the actual placement, and a final post-placement phase, consisting of seminars on reflection and the assessment, and culminating in a practice Graduate Assessment Centre.

Pre-placement seminars:
- Researching potential employers and securing a placement; CV tailoring and preparing for application processes.
- Introduction to employability and reflective theory; how to effectively reflect and log reflections.
- Getting the most from the placement experience; health and safety; professional conduct.

Placement:
- This will either be a ‘traditional’ placement at a commercial, research, charitable, or similar organisation, or an in-house virtual placement, delivered via collaboration with C&E and the Centre for Innovation in Education.

Post-placement activity:
- Reflecting on skills development and articulation.
- Group shared reflections on personal and peers’ experiences.
- Practice Graduate Assessment Centre.
Teaching and Learning Methods
This module will be taught via a number of pre-placement seminars that will assist students in finding a ‘traditional’ placement, prepare them for placement work, introduce them to the employability theory, and introduce reflective assessment. A significant component of the module will be the placement itself, which will either be a traditional placement, or a virtual placement. In both cases, students will have the opportunity to develop their confidence, and graduate-level employability skills such as digital fluency, collaboration, and problem solving, applying the knowledge and expertise they have developed in the first five semesters of their studies. Post-placement seminars will focus on reflective practice, incorporate group work, and result in the finalising of the portfolio assessment. Students will engage in teamwork within the pre- and post-placement sessions. At the end of the module a practice Graduate Assessment Centre, a typical part of the graduate recruitment process for many organisations, will consolidate student knowledge, skills development, and articulation of both.

The teaching and learning strategy have been guided by the Liverpool Curriculum Framework attributes and hallmarks, particularly with respect to inclusivity, digital fluency, active learning, and confidence. Students will have access to all teaching materials online, and online discussion boards will offer additional student support. Seminars will be recorded to enable students to access materials asynchronously. Where appropriate, students will be encouraged to work in small groups to discuss relevant issues and share with each other their experiences and perspectives. Students will be encouraged and supported to make full contributions to discussions, learning tasks, and their placement activity. They will be given ongoing constructive feedback on areas to improve in terms of reflective writing and placement engagement.

Attendance at all seminars will be monitored, and effective engagement with placement activity will be monitored through regular additions to the reflective portfolio at defined intervals.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Assessment strategy has been guided by the Liverpool Curriculum Framework attributes and hallmarks, particularly with respect to confidence, active learning, digital fluency, and authentic assessment. Students will be assessed via a reflective portfolio reflecting on, and evidencing, their personal development, during the course of the module.

The portfolio will be required, as a minimum, to include the following elements:

- The student’s CV at the start of the module, in year 2 semester 2.
- A skills audit at the start of the module that identifies the transferable skills student’s wish to develop further through work experience.
- A series of reflective logs detailing the student’s skills and values development through the course of their placement, with reference, where appropriate, to the employability and reflective theory.
- A skills audit at the end of the module that allows students to reflect generally on their transferable skills development.
- The student’s CV at the end of the module in year 3, semester 2.
- Evidence that they attended and completed the practice Graduate Assessment Centre.

Reassessment will use the same format. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Overview

Students will be made fully aware of these expenses, and the possibility of reimbursement will be considered on individual basis, where appropriate.

Students will be made fully aware of these expenses, and the possibility of reimbursement will be considered on individual basis, where appropriate.

Pre-placement seminars:
- Researching potential employers and securing a placement; CV tailoring and preparing for application processes.
- Introduction to employability and reflective theory; how to effectively reflect and log reflections.
- Getting the most from the placement experience; health and safety; professional conduct.

Placement:
- This will either be a ‘traditional’ placement at a commercial, research, charitable, or similar organisation, or an in-house virtual placement, delivered via collaboration with C&E and the Centre for Innovation in Education.

Post-placement activity:
- Reflecting on skills development and articulation.
- Group shared reflections on personal and peers’ experiences.
- Practice Graduate Assessment Centre.
Teaching and Learning Methods
This module will be taught via a number of pre-placement seminars that will assist students in finding a ‘traditional’ placement, prepare them for placement work, introduce them to the employability theory, and introduce reflective assessment. A significant component of the module will be the placement itself, which will either be a traditional placement, or a virtual placement. In both cases, students will have the opportunity to develop their confidence, and graduate-level employability skills such as digital fluency, collaboration, and problem solving, applying the knowledge and expertise they have developed in the first five semesters of their studies. Post-placement seminars will focus on reflective practice, incorporate group work, and result in the finalising of the portfolio assessment. Students will engage in teamwork within the pre- and post-placement sessions. At the end of the module a practice Graduate Assessment Centre, a typical part of the graduate recruitment process for many organisations, will consolidate student knowledge, skills development, and articulation of both.

The teaching and learning strategy have been guided by the Liverpool Curriculum Framework attributes and hallmarks, particularly with respect to inclusivity, digital fluency, active learning, and confidence. Students will have access to all teaching materials online, and online discussion boards will offer additional student support. Seminars will be recorded to enable students to access materials asynchronously. Where appropriate, students will be encouraged to work in small groups to discuss relevant issues and share with each other their experiences and perspectives. Students will be encouraged and supported to make full contributions to discussions, learning tasks, and their placement activity. They will be given ongoing constructive feedback on areas to improve in terms of reflective writing and placement engagement.

Attendance at all seminars will be monitored, and effective engagement with placement activity will be monitored through regular additions to the reflective portfolio at defined intervals.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Assessment strategy has been guided by the Liverpool Curriculum Framework attributes and hallmarks, particularly with respect to confidence, active learning, digital fluency, and authentic assessment. Students will be assessed via a reflective portfolio reflecting on, and evidencing, their personal development, during the course of the module.

The portfolio will be required, as a minimum, to include the following elements:

- The student’s CV at the start of the module, in year 2 semester 2.
- A skills audit at the start of the module that identifies the transferable skills student’s wish to develop further through work experience.
- A series of reflective logs detailing the student’s skills and values development through the course of their placement, with reference, where appropriate, to the employability and reflective theory.
- A skills audit at the end of the module that allows students to reflect generally on their transferable skills development.
- The student’s CV at the end of the module in year 3, semester 2.
- Evidence that they attended and completed the practice Graduate Assessment Centre.

Reassessment will use the same format. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

BIOS302
Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2024, starting with year 1.

Overview

Overview
All students will benefit from a series of skills training sessions in semester 2 of year 2, delivered by Careers & Employability (C&E). They will be encouraged to seek a ‘traditional’ placement that will help them develop graduate-level skills, in any professional sector. If students are successful in obtaining a placement, this will be undertaken in the summer between years 2 and 3.

If students are not successful in obtaining, or do not wish to undertake a ‘traditional’ placement, they will instead engage in a virtual placement, to be undertaken either in the summer, or in semester 1 of year 3. Students will choose from one of four broad categories of placement, public health, environment and sustainability, biotechnology, and general careers. By engaging with skills development activities online, students will further develop their employability skills such as critical thinking, interpretation, and communication.

In semester 2 of year 3, all students will undertake a further series of training sessions, incorporating group work, and again delivered by C&E. All students, regardless of which placement activity they undertake, will be assessed via a reflective portfolio, that they will develop throughout their engagement with the module activities.

For those students undertaking a placement external to the university, costs may be associated with travel to and from the student’s placement site, and (temporary) accommodation if the student has to stay away from their normal term-time accommodation whilst attending the placement. Students will be made fully aware of these expenses, and the possibility of reimbursement will be considered on individual basis, where appropriate.
Educational Aims
The aim of this module is to prepare students for graduate-level work. The module aims to give students the opportunity to further develop their skills and professional behaviours, reflect on them, and evidence them for future employment.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This 15-credit year three module acts as a steppingstone for students into the world of work. The module will utilise and develop knowledge, understanding, and skills that students have acquired during their first five semesters of study. Incorporating a placement, it will provide an opportunity for students to improve skills that are particularly sought after by employers, such as problem solving, teamwork, and communication, and will train them to better recognise, evidence, and articulate their skillset to future employers. The module will be assessed via a reflective portfolio, that they will develop throughout their engagement with the module activities.

For those students undertaking a placement external to the university, costs may be associated with travel to and from the student’s placement site, and (temporary) accommodation if the student has to stay away from their normal term-time accommodation whilst attending the placement. Students will be made fully aware of these expenses, and the possibility of reimbursement will be considered on individual basis, where appropriate.
Outline Syllabus
This module will be divided into a pre-placement phase, consisting of seminars for preparation to the placement, a core applied phase, consisting of the actual placement, and a final post-placement phase, consisting of seminars on reflection and the assessment, and culminating in a practice Graduate Assessment Centre.

Pre-placement seminars:
- Researching potential employers and securing a placement; CV tailoring and preparing for application processes.
- Introduction to employability and reflective theory; how to effectively reflect and log reflections.
- Getting the most from the placement experience; health and safety; professional conduct.

Placement:
- This will either be a ‘traditional’ placement at a commercial, research, charitable, or similar organisation, or an in-house virtual placement, delivered via collaboration with C&E and the Centre for Innovation in Education.

Post-placement activity:
- Reflecting on skills development and articulation.
- Group shared reflections on personal and peers’ experiences.
- Practice Graduate Assessment Centre.
Teaching and Learning Methods
This module will be taught via a number of pre-placement seminars that will assist students in finding a ‘traditional’ placement, prepare them for placement work, introduce them to the employability theory, and introduce reflective assessment. A significant component of the module will be the placement itself, which will either be a traditional placement, or a virtual placement. In both cases, students will have the opportunity to develop their confidence, and graduate-level employability skills such as digital fluency, collaboration, and problem solving, applying the knowledge and expertise they have developed in the first five semesters of their studies. Post-placement seminars will focus on reflective practice, incorporate group work, and result in the finalising of the portfolio assessment. Students will engage in teamwork within the pre- and post-placement sessions. At the end of the module a practice Graduate Assessment Centre, a typical part of the graduate recruitment process for many organisations, will consolidate student knowledge, skills development, and articulation of both.

The teaching and learning strategy have been guided by the Liverpool Curriculum Framework attributes and hallmarks, particularly with respect to inclusivity, digital fluency, active learning, and confidence. Students will have access to all teaching materials online, and online discussion boards will offer additional student support. Seminars will be recorded to enable students to access materials asynchronously. Where appropriate, students will be encouraged to work in small groups to discuss relevant issues and share with each other their experiences and perspectives. Students will be encouraged and supported to make full contributions to discussions, learning tasks, and their placement activity. They will be given ongoing constructive feedback on areas to improve in terms of reflective writing and placement engagement.

Attendance at all seminars will be monitored, and effective engagement with placement activity will be monitored through regular additions to the reflective portfolio at defined intervals.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Assessment strategy has been guided by the Liverpool Curriculum Framework attributes and hallmarks, particularly with respect to confidence, active learning, digital fluency, and authentic assessment. Students will be assessed via a reflective portfolio reflecting on, and evidencing, their personal development, during the course of the module.

The portfolio will be required, as a minimum, to include the following elements:

- The student’s CV at the start of the module, in year 2 semester 2.
- A skills audit at the start of the module that identifies the transferable skills student’s wish to develop further through work experience.
- A series of reflective logs detailing the student’s skills and values development through the course of their placement, with reference, where appropriate, to the employability and reflective theory.
- A skills audit at the end of the module that allows students to reflect generally on their transferable skills development.
- The student’s CV at the end of the module in year 3, semester 2.
- Evidence that they attended and completed the practice Graduate Assessment Centre.

Reassessment will use the same format. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Students will be made fully aware of these expenses, and the possibility of reimbursement will be considered on individual basis, where appropriate.
Outline Syllabus
This module will be divided into a pre-placement phase, consisting of seminars for preparation to the placement, a core applied phase, consisting of the actual placement, and a final post-placement phase, consisting of seminars on reflection and the assessment, and culminating in a practice Graduate Assessment Centre.

Pre-placement seminars:
- Researching potential employers and securing a placement; CV tailoring and preparing for application processes.
- Introduction to employability and reflective theory; how to effectively reflect and log reflections.
- Getting the most from the placement experience; health and safety; professional conduct.

Placement:
- This will either be a ‘traditional’ placement at a commercial, research, charitable, or similar organisation, or an in-house virtual placement, delivered via collaboration with C&E and the Centre for Innovation in Education.

Post-placement activity:
- Reflecting on skills development and articulation.
- Group shared reflections on personal and peers’ experiences.
- Practice Graduate Assessment Centre.
Teaching and Learning Methods
This module will be taught via a number of pre-placement seminars that will assist students in finding a ‘traditional’ placement, prepare them for placement work, introduce them to the employability theory, and introduce reflective assessment. A significant component of the module will be the placement itself, which will either be a traditional placement, or a virtual placement. In both cases, students will have the opportunity to develop their confidence, and graduate-level employability skills such as digital fluency, collaboration, and problem solving, applying the knowledge and expertise they have developed in the first five semesters of their studies. Post-placement seminars will focus on reflective practice, incorporate group work, and result in the finalising of the portfolio assessment. Students will engage in teamwork within the pre- and post-placement sessions. At the end of the module a practice Graduate Assessment Centre, a typical part of the graduate recruitment process for many organisations, will consolidate student knowledge, skills development, and articulation of both.

The teaching and learning strategy have been guided by the Liverpool Curriculum Framework attributes and hallmarks, particularly with respect to inclusivity, digital fluency, active learning, and confidence. Students will have access to all teaching materials online, and online discussion boards will offer additional student support. Seminars will be recorded to enable students to access materials asynchronously. Where appropriate, students will be encouraged to work in small groups to discuss relevant issues and share with each other their experiences and perspectives. Students will be encouraged and supported to make full contributions to discussions, learning tasks, and their placement activity. They will be given ongoing constructive feedback on areas to improve in terms of reflective writing and placement engagement.

Attendance at all seminars will be monitored, and effective engagement with placement activity will be monitored through regular additions to the reflective portfolio at defined intervals.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Assessment strategy has been guided by the Liverpool Curriculum Framework attributes and hallmarks, particularly with respect to confidence, active learning, digital fluency, and authentic assessment. Students will be assessed via a reflective portfolio reflecting on, and evidencing, their personal development, during the course of the module.

The portfolio will be required, as a minimum, to include the following elements:

- The student’s CV at the start of the module, in year 2 semester 2.
- A skills audit at the start of the module that identifies the transferable skills student’s wish to develop further through work experience.
- A series of reflective logs detailing the student’s skills and values development through the course of their placement, with reference, where appropriate, to the employability and reflective theory.
- A skills audit at the end of the module that allows students to reflect generally on their transferable skills development.
- The student’s CV at the end of the module in year 3, semester 2.
- Evidence that they attended and completed the practice Graduate Assessment Centre.

Reassessment will use the same format. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2024, starting with year 1.

Overview

Overview
All students will benefit from a series of skills training sessions in semester 2 of year 2, delivered by Careers & Employability (C&E). They will be encouraged to seek a ‘traditional’ placement that will help them develop graduate-level skills, in any professional sector. If students are successful in obtaining a placement, this will be undertaken in the summer between years 2 and 3.

If students are not successful in obtaining, or do not wish to undertake a ‘traditional’ placement, they will instead engage in a virtual placement, to be undertaken either in the summer, or in semester 1 of year 3. Students will choose from one of four broad categories of placement, public health, environment and sustainability, biotechnology, and general careers. By engaging with skills development activities online, students will further develop their employability skills such as critical thinking, interpretation, and communication.

In semester 2 of year 3, all students will undertake a further series of training sessions, incorporating group work, and again delivered by C&E. All students, regardless of which placement activity they undertake, will be assessed via a reflective portfolio, that they will develop throughout their engagement with the module activities.

For those students undertaking a placement external to the university, costs may be associated with travel to and from the student’s placement site, and (temporary) accommodation if the student has to stay away from their normal term-time accommodation whilst attending the placement. Students will be made fully aware of these expenses, and the possibility of reimbursement will be considered on individual basis, where appropriate.
Educational Aims
The aim of this module is to prepare students for graduate-level work. The module aims to give students the opportunity to further develop their skills and professional behaviours, reflect on them, and evidence them for future employment.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This 15-credit year three module acts as a steppingstone for students into the world of work. The module will utilise and develop knowledge, understanding, and skills that students have acquired during their first five semesters of study. Incorporating a placement, it will provide an opportunity for students to improve skills that are particularly sought after by employers, such as problem solving, teamwork, and communication, and will train them to better recognise, evidence, and articulate their skillset to future employers. The module will be assessed via a reflective portfolio, that they will develop throughout their engagement with the module activities.

For those students undertaking a placement external to the university, costs may be associated with travel to and from the student’s placement site, and (temporary) accommodation if the student has to stay away from their normal term-time accommodation whilst attending the placement. Students will be made fully aware of these expenses, and the possibility of reimbursement will be considered on individual basis, where appropriate.
Outline Syllabus
This module will be divided into a pre-placement phase, consisting of seminars for preparation to the placement, a core applied phase, consisting of the actual placement, and a final post-placement phase, consisting of seminars on reflection and the assessment, and culminating in a practice Graduate Assessment Centre.

Pre-placement seminars:
- Researching potential employers and securing a placement; CV tailoring and preparing for application processes.
- Introduction to employability and reflective theory; how to effectively reflect and log reflections.
- Getting the most from the placement experience; health and safety; professional conduct.

Placement:
- This will either be a ‘traditional’ placement at a commercial, research, charitable, or similar organisation, or an in-house virtual placement, delivered via collaboration with C&E and the Centre for Innovation in Education.

Post-placement activity:
- Reflecting on skills development and articulation.
- Group shared reflections on personal and peers’ experiences.
- Practice Graduate Assessment Centre.
Teaching and Learning Methods
This module will be taught via a number of pre-placement seminars that will assist students in finding a ‘traditional’ placement, prepare them for placement work, introduce them to the employability theory, and introduce reflective assessment. A significant component of the module will be the placement itself, which will either be a traditional placement, or a virtual placement. In both cases, students will have the opportunity to develop their confidence, and graduate-level employability skills such as digital fluency, collaboration, and problem solving, applying the knowledge and expertise they have developed in the first five semesters of their studies. Post-placement seminars will focus on reflective practice, incorporate group work, and result in the finalising of the portfolio assessment. Students will engage in teamwork within the pre- and post-placement sessions. At the end of the module a practice Graduate Assessment Centre, a typical part of the graduate recruitment process for many organisations, will consolidate student knowledge, skills development, and articulation of both.

The teaching and learning strategy have been guided by the Liverpool Curriculum Framework attributes and hallmarks, particularly with respect to inclusivity, digital fluency, active learning, and confidence. Students will have access to all teaching materials online, and online discussion boards will offer additional student support. Seminars will be recorded to enable students to access materials asynchronously. Where appropriate, students will be encouraged to work in small groups to discuss relevant issues and share with each other their experiences and perspectives. Students will be encouraged and supported to make full contributions to discussions, learning tasks, and their placement activity. They will be given ongoing constructive feedback on areas to improve in terms of reflective writing and placement engagement.

Attendance at all seminars will be monitored, and effective engagement with placement activity will be monitored through regular additions to the reflective portfolio at defined intervals.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Assessment strategy has been guided by the Liverpool Curriculum Framework attributes and hallmarks, particularly with respect to confidence, active learning, digital fluency, and authentic assessment. Students will be assessed via a reflective portfolio reflecting on, and evidencing, their personal development, during the course of the module.

The portfolio will be required, as a minimum, to include the following elements:

- The student’s CV at the start of the module, in year 2 semester 2.
- A skills audit at the start of the module that identifies the transferable skills student’s wish to develop further through work experience.
- A series of reflective logs detailing the student’s skills and values development through the course of their placement, with reference, where appropriate, to the employability and reflective theory.
- A skills audit at the end of the module that allows students to reflect generally on their transferable skills development.
- The student’s CV at the end of the module in year 3, semester 2.
- Evidence that they attended and completed the practice Graduate Assessment Centre.

Reassessment will use the same format. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
